title: Is there existing ancient Egyptian lore regarding the racial diversity present in that society at the time? - Quora

response.answer_text: First of all, all Egyptians ARE African, except for people living in Sinai (which is located in Asia technically).. This applies to modern and ancient Egyptians.The book you are referring to might be a one I’ve read before. It was showing depictions of different nations, they were not all Egyptians. I’m almost sure it contains photos like this:  Which actually depicts a Libyan, a Kushite, a Syrian and a typical Egyptian.(Ps, the picture was collected from different locations, it wasn’t originally intended to show differences between nations.. The pictures aren’t also the only way these nations were portrayed) With that out of the way, let me also point out that African doesn’t equal Black, and that applies to a lot of other nations not only Egyptians. The whole racial thing is totally foreign for Egyptians, we never ever think of it, I only knew it was an issue after seeing debates between Americans (typically not based on any knowledge). That’s in modern Egypt.Now, regarding ancient Egypt, it is actually the same, there were no laws and no mention of treatments of people based on skin tone, if you are an Egyptian, you are an Egyptian and that’s it. I feel my answer was anti-climatic, sorry about that… Please ask for more details if needed.

Ancient Egyptians DID NOT portray themselves as black. They portrayed themselves as brown, Mid East people, Europeans and Libyans as white! This is how Egyptians portrayed black Africans:  They portrayed themselves as brown   They portrayed Semites/Libyans as white   Ancient Egyptians debunk Afrocentric lies!
